p: Two main patterns arose: some indices were strongly dependent from all the driving factors (red columns in Fig. 6), whereas some factors affected most of the indices (red rows). Besides, some indices, like the cold spell duration index (CSDI), were not significantly driven ( p > 0.05) by any factor. Evapotranspiration- and rain-related indices (i.e., SAM and rx1day) were the most affected by the factors considered (as highlighted by thick red columns). Some factors, i.e., WG, Site × WG, Site and GCM (red rows), appeared to be the most influential for the majority of climate indices. Overall, GCM was the least significant factor, its average p-value being about 150% larger than for Site and about one order of magnitude larger than for WG. Results also indicated that influential factors are – to a certain extent – uniformly significant ( p < 0.05) across different indices.
